_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Bridgeport Gas Plant is a natural gas condensate, amine treating and gas dehydration facility ("Facility"), which utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a "regulated flammable substance (10,000 pounds)" in the processing of natural gas.  The natural gas condensate is an RMP-regulated flammable mixture.  Therefore, this Facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 



The Bridgeport Gas Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and public receptors are located within the worst-case release scenario for the plant.  Therefore, the Bridgeport Gas Plant is subject to Program 3 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in USEPA's RMP Rule.  All elements required by USEPA's 40 CFR 68 - Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM. 



Within the last five (5) years, the Bridgeport Gas Plant has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.  



The Bridgeport Gas Plant employs 58 full-time employees on-site who ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility.  



EnLink Midstream Operating, L.P. (EnLink), formerly Devon Energy Corporation, last submitted a full RMP the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) in July 2013 for the Bridgeport Gas Plant.  The current RMP includes administrative updates addressing the change from Devon Energy Corporation to EnLink, Facility modifications, and is being submitted

as a full 5-year update.   



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Bridgeport Gas Plant maintains a policy of safe natural gas condensate separation operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the separation processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.    



The Bridgeport Gas Plant has procedures in place, including both on-site activities and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a natural gas condensate release.



DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Bridgeport Gas Plant separates natural gas condensate from raw inlet gas in various aboveground vessels and associated piping and valves.  Natural gas condensate is a flammable hydrocarbon mixture that may contain the following RMP-regulated flammables: isobutane, N-butane, neopentane (2,2-dimethylpropane), isopentane, and N-pentane.    Although natural gas condensate is often classified as an NFPA Class 3 flammable substance, testing completed by EnLink demonstrates that the mixture would, at times, be considered an NFPA Class 4 flammable based upon the flash point and boiling point of the mixture. As such, EnLink has chosen to include natural gas condensate in the RMP-regulated inventory.



The Facility also stores and processes the following RMP-regulated substances: natural gasoline, ethyl mercaptan, natural gas liquids (NGL), propane, isobutane, N-butane, and ethane.  NGL is a flammable mixture that contains propane, ethane, N-butane, isobutane, isopentane, N-pentane, and methane; isobutane is a flammable mixture that contains propane, N-butane, and isobutane; ethane is a flammable mixture that contains propane, ethane, and methane; natural gasoline is a flammable mixture that contains Isopentane and pentane.   Propane ethyl mercaptan, and N-butane are stored at the Facility in their pure form.  



The following provide

s the maximum storage capacity and largest vessel capacity, calculated using 100 percent vessel capacity, for all of the RMP-regulated flammables stored at the Bridgeport Gas Plant.



RMP STORAGE INVENTORY



Substance

Natural Gasoline: Maximum inventory 2,937,862 pounds; Largest vessel 303,650 pounds

Ethane: Maximum inventory 37,576 pounds; Largest vessel 21,454 pounds 

Ethyl Mercaptan: Maximum inventory 32,427 pounds; Largest vessel 29,479 pounds 

Isobutane: Maximum inventory 704,894 pounds; Largest vessel 182,768 pounds 

N-butane: Maximum inventory 1,351,498 pounds; Largest vessel 242,491 pounds 

Natural Gas Liquids: Maximum inventory 673,631 pounds; Largest vessel 124,946 pounds 

Propane: Maximum inventory 4,705,753 pounds; Largest vessel 301,121 pounds

Natural Gas Condensate: Maximum inventory 5,055,845; Largest vessel 731,755



The Bridgeport Gas Plant stores natural gasoline and natural gas condensate, which under certain circumstances, are not classified as RMP-regulated flammable mixtures.  Although the current Facility Material Safety Data Sheets for natural gasoline and natural gas condensate lists them as National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) Class 3 flammables, subsequent testing completed by EnLink demonstrates that the mixtures would, at times, be considered NFPA Class 4 flammables based upon the flash point and boiling point of the mixtures.  As such, EnLink has chosen to include natural gasoline and natural gas condensate in the RMP-regulated inventory at the Facility.   



The Bridgeport Gas Plant is also an amine treatment facility.  EnLink has reviewed amine used at the Bridgeport Gas Plant and determined that it is not RMP-regulated due to its lack of RMP-regulated components.



The Bridgeport Gas Plant is also an amine treatment facility.  EnLink has reviewed amine used at the Bridgeport Gas Plant and determined that it is not RMP-regulated due to its lack of RMP-regulated components.

, EnLink conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Facility provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.



SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS



EnLink has a continued commitment to update equipment and improve safety pertaining to the covered process when necessary.  The most recent Process Hazard Analysis for the Facility was completed on May 4, 2015.
